author: m.kalinin
content: You'd need `>1/2` of total stake to be able to orphan blocks that contain particular transactions if the network has good synchronicity conditions and probably less if not. But if `>1/2` of a stake is adversarial there is possibility of a network split which is more sever security violation than censorship.

author: sky.cactus
content: Hmm, will the 51% who are censoring just eventually cause the 49% to bleed out?

author: m.kalinin
content: Probably yes but it will be rather slow (votes to the head of the chain will be incorrect and some ffg.target votes too), but attestation may be censored to speed up leaking

author: sky.cactus
content:
The flow would be something like this?
1. A non-censoring block producer produces a block.
2. 49% (non-censoring) validators sign the block.
3. 51% (censoring) validators refuse to sign the block.
4. Next block producer is non-censoring, so the whole thing happens with now a 2 deep chain.
5. Next block producer is censoring, they produce a sibling to the first censored block (not building on that chain).
6. 49% refuse to sign it (would be a double sign and result in slashing).
7. 51% sign.
8. *Eventually* the longest chain would be the censoring chain, at which point the 49% will start signing blocks on top of that.

author: sky.cactus
content: Does that sound about right?

author: m.kalinin
content: 5. They does not produce a sibling, they produce a block on top of the previous censoring block leaving a couple of slots empty. And non-censoring minority could still vote on this block without violating slashing conditions

author: mrabino1
content:
Without announcing specifics, giving broad guidance to allow rational miners to forecast their hw capital outlay I believe will help reduce the possibilities for contention as we approach the merge. It may ‚Äúfeel‚Äù early to start announcing any guidance; however, from my lens, estimating the avg lifespan of mining hw, the decision window to communicate to miners is now / rapidly approaching. 

Steps forward like the recent announcing the possibility of prioritizing the merge after an upcoming fork go a long-way to help miners make reasonable decisions. My hope is that the community can / will convey one layer further in specifics (more than priority) going to the targeted in X months for development and another Y months for testing (with huge emphasis on targeted but it is guidance nevertheless).

(and yeah, there is the political risk to the foundation / community and more importantly to the security of the powchain if that guidance is waaay off)

Miners have played an essential role since the launch. It is easy to crap on them today as being ‚Äúgreedy‚Äù when the situation that has played out RE high-fees is by-in-large not caused by them. With that in mind, PoS has been on the roadmap since PoW genesis, and no one has yet ever made / forced a miner to purchase hw or mine. Every assumption ever made for ** any ** investment decision always include inherit risks that assumptions may differ from what actually happens (e.g. 1559 and the merge). Of course, assumptions are based on the situation at the time and disclosures. 

My objective with the above is that providing guidance when folks are making their investment decisions will help. It is of course not without risk to Ethereum. If done too early, the hash power for PoW may start to fall too soon due to lack of capital investment in hw mining. Though where the PoS chain is, along with overall state of ‚Äúthe merge‚Äù, the timing is quite close to ‚Äúright‚Äù. My $0.02

author: m.kalinin
content: There is possibility for some party to start building own fork which will grow faster than the mainnet in terms of block numbers; this fork is being built and withheld until it reaches the transition block number. Then this party may bribe a proposer or wait until its own validator is ready to propose and propose the first PoS block on top of that minority fork. While the fork may also complete a double spent attack.

author: draganrakita
content: okay, then every proposer can trigger `merge` and to dodge that and be sure that no fake block are miner for sake of block number we are looking at difficulty

author: m.kalinin
content:
The merge is very complicated in terms of implementation and testing. Testing involves checking that all existing infrastructure works after the merge and during the transition, applications, exchangers, explorers. Also, some of the infra will have to be modified e.g. explorers.

I would say that X _may_ land in Q4. Y will be started earlier and definitely last longer, but it is not yet decided how much time it will need to drive production ready testnet without failures to convince the community that it is safe enough to move forward.

author: m.kalinin
content: right, a certain amount of hashpower would be required to be contributed to the mainnet to make the transition happen
